Posts.Content: Hi Fretty so sorry to hear of your situation which is similar to mine. I was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2012. Had lump and lymph nodes removed, chemo and then radio then in May/June of this year returned to my neck found by Ultra sound and biopsy. Had a CT scan and will be starting 6 weeks of intensive radio on the neck on Monday 15th July. I've been told that this may not clear it and if it does may "pop" up again somewhere else which is not what I wanted to hear. However there are other treatments which we can be given including more chemo and hormone tablets so please try to be positive. I have contacted a few other people that are in similar situations as us and some have lived full and active lives for years and years and still going strong so don't loose heart. Good luck with the scan.
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Reoccurance

Posts.Content: Morning all, went for my 1st Docetaxel yesterday. Saw the onc first who satisfied my fears. Giving me 20% less as I was so sick on my 1st FEC and ended up in hospital for a week netropenic and with infection. So 2nd and 3rd FEC reduced by 20%. Also given emend for sickness which worked well on the FEC and seems to be doing the same with this, and most importantly to be given the one off injection today by district nurse for infection which I also had with FEC following my 1st disaster which solves my problem of having to inject myself, NO WAY which I blogged on here about which all you lovely ladies tried to help me with your own experiences but which I still couldn’t get my head around. So all in all RESULT. Apart from feeling spaced out and tired at present feeling OK, just waiting for the side effects to kick in whatever they may be but He Ho the joys of chemo! After spending 8 hours at the hospital yesterday with husband came home and relaxed with a non alcoholic beer (Blue Becks) whilst husband prepared and cooked dinner, he’s a star. Hope you all are coping OK will let you all know how I go!
Posts.Title: 1ST DOCETAXEL YESTERDAY

Posts.Content: Hi Shawshank that’s just appalling, unacceptable. It’s the worrying that’s the worse. Once you know your fate most of us on here can cope by taking each day at a time but with a plan, not like you without, your head must be all over the place. I’m speechless but please try to stay strong and positive whatever life throws at us we can meet it head on and deal with it. Take care. xx
Posts.Title: still waitin

Posts.Content: Hi Mary what a lovely tale you have lifted my spirits today. Thank you for sharing this and congratulations on finishing chemo. I have had 3 FEC and 1 T just 2 more to go (yippee) and struggling onwards as we do and I like everyone get my down days which impacts on our ever loyal supportive husbands who never stop believing and keep us strong. Mine is there 24/7 (we are both retired ) comes to every appointment, cooks, cleans, shops and makes me laugh and on the good week takes me shopping, day trips to the beach, takes me to the local and wines and dines me. My trip started end of March this year and I would never have got this far without him. So as the song says:- “LET’S HEAR IT FOR THE BOY”
Posts.Title: A post chemo smile!

Posts.Content: Hi Kelly I had such a bad reaction from my 1st FEC that they reduced the dose by 20% which also applied to the Docetaxel. Had my last one Thursday. I still got aching bones which I was given tramadol and sore mouth (thrush) which I was given nystan, both worked well and kept me active. Horrid taste buds forced me to eat mostly sweet things which I would not normally eat but he ho what a price to pay! I’m sure you will also find you can handle this last stage. The chemo generally has an accumulative effect so gets a bit harder each time to recover but get there I do and as for understanding if the reduced dose works as good, my idea is how can something that gives us such horrid side effects NOT WORK! Good luck and keep positive soon be over.
Posts.Title: Docetaxel reduced dose

Posts.Content: Happy New Year to you all. I am lucky that I have finished the chemo and radio just on hormones for the next 5 years or so. Still trying to cope with the after effects/shock and get back to normal which I know from others will not be quick or easy. In an effort to push this forward my husband who has been my rock and I would like to start planning holidays for 2013 but are finding it difficult to find any reasonably priced travel insurance. If anyone has any experience of this can you share with us. Good luck to all those who are struggling to get where I am. All I can say is it’s doable and you will find the hidden strength that you didn’t know you had but it’s there, just tap into it.
Posts.Title: TRAVEL INSURANCE

Posts.Content: Thanks to you all who have replied to me, got the insurance sorted with “Allclear” who are covering me with Hypothyroidism, breast cancer and osteoporosis and my husband with diabetes mellitus for £323.09 annual multi trip Europe so well pleased as will be going on three trips abroad this year as well as UK. Staysure did a similar cover for £425.77.
Posts.Title: TRAVEL INSURANCE

Posts.Content: Hi Janice glad to here all is going great for you and thank you for expressing yourself. I was diagnoised April this year. I've had two ops and now halfway through chemo then onto radio. At present not too bad and still positive but there are times when I think will I ever get my life back, but you have solved that YES I WILL. Thanks again. xxx
Posts.Title: Living again

Posts.Content: Hi Sheila I had a PICC line put in following my 1st chemo as I ended up in hospital and was put on anti - biotic which were also put through a cannula. I have very narrow veins and apart from the problems with insertion (several attempts each time) I am needle phobic and experienced constant pain. I had my last chemo last week (yippee) and having the PICC line put in was the best decision I have made. As already advised all the chemo goes through the line and the bloods come out so no more painful insertions. I experienced most of the different side effects with chemo but with the help of medication was able to cope so make sure you shout nobody mines and there’s a lot of help out there. Good luck with your journey and try not to get too stressed, and remember to rest as much as you can, you can do it the same as the rest of us. Lots of virtual hugs.
Posts.Title: New to the Group worrying about the whole Breast Cancer situation...

Posts.Content: Hi Kittycat Sorry you are not getting better as quick as you thought and good luck with the surgery on Thursday. I’ve only had one “T” next one tomorrow and must say I’ve been watching your journey and taken heed of all you have had to say, you have helped me cope as have a lot of the other lovely ladies on this site. Must admit that I was alarmed to read that the effects of “T” take a lot longer to get out of your system then I first expected but just keep trying to be positive and get through the next two. I’m lucky that I’ve had all the surgery done prior to having chemo and should now only need radio and then the hormone tablets. Been looking at holidays for next year as had to cancel all for this year when diagnosed but thinking mustn’t run before I can walk. As everyone says we are all different and recovery will be different for each of us but it is still very frustrating. It’s a bit like the mind is willing but the flesh is weak. Here’s hoping that following your surgery you start to get better and stronger day by day and that all this horror will soon be a distant memory. When you feel like it please keep us posted on your recovery and again good luck with tomorrow I will be thinking of you. Hugs
Posts.Title: Docetaxal - how long until you feel better??!!

Posts.Content: Hi I have recently joined Macmillan. I am 61 and I was diagnoised with breast cancer April of this year. I have had 2 ops the last one to remove 14 lymph nodes which has left me with a manageable but niggly nerve pain. If anyone has any experience of this please advise. Anyhow last week I had my first of 3 FEC-T chemo's which was horrible. I was unable to eat, sleep or do anything much for 4/5 days. Got very depressed and tearful which was not nice for my husband who with my family and friends is doing a fantatic job of looking after and encouraging me. I am OK now but not looking forward to the rest. In an effort to keep positive I am thinking of joining a gym, has anyone got any advice/suggections/experience of this that would assist me in making this decesion. I understand that this would be good for me during and after treatment has been completed. Thx
Posts.Title: GYM

Posts.Content: Hi Kittycat so glad for you well done. Followed your mails as had similar reactions as you and PICC line, seeing how you coped has kept me going. Not able to mail very often problem with my browser but look each day. I’m a bit behind you only had 1st “T” last week no side effects as yet but looking forward to the end of October for my last one. I’ve had the operations so just radio and hormones can’t wait just want my life back. Like you had lots of support and assistance from family and friends and especially my husband who has pulled out all the stops to keep us both strong with such affection and most importantly with humour. We laugh a lot at the silliest things. Good luck with the rest of your journey, stay strong I will be watching and encouraging from the side lines. xx
Posts.Title: Chemo ends - Where's the wine and the tissues?!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Michele I started to lose mine 14 days after 1st FEC. It started by bits coming out and after a few days asks husband to get out his clippers and do a number one all over as it looked like the moths had been at it. Glad I did it first as last as seemed to cope better. Now don’t worry about it at all, in fact husband has to remind me to put something on my head when we go out as I often forget. I invested in a wig for the goods times when we can go out for a drink and a meal and a few hats and scarfs for the rest. Everyone’s different on this journey just try not to worry and take each day as it comes. Good luck next week, another one to tick off!
Posts.Title: When can I expect hair loss with FEC

Posts.Content: I had a PICC line put in following a not very good reaction to my first FEC. It was put in by a local and no problem. Had second FEC and went easily. The PICC line can also be used for blood tests and in my case in hospital for anti biotics due to low white blood cell count which for me works great as I have very narrow veins and they are hard to detect so always end up black and blue and very scared. So glad I made the investment. FEC 3 is next week (1/2 way yepee) then onto Docetaxel for 3 lots. Once the lines in I am visited by the district nurse once a week who cleans and redresses it. I've had no problems with it so far. They provide you with a "Limbo" which is an arm sleeve to cover for shower use. If you have any further questions ask away and good luck to you, you will be fine.
Posts.Title: New with PICC line

Posts.Content: Hi Sammy I had my FEC reduced by 20% after my first one when I also ended up in hospital for 3 days with high temperature and infection and this was carried on with the Tax as well. I asked the question “would it still work” and was told that yes it would and that lots of people have to have their dosage reduced for various reasons. So do not worry the experts know what their doing. I had all the usual side effects and am still on tramadol for pain following my last Tax which was two weeks ago. Just hoping I can get off them prior to starting the radio on the 26th. If you still feel worried ask the onc when you go next he or she will put your mind at rest. Good luck with the rest of your treatment and stay positive it’s a great feeling once completed.
Posts.Title: Reduction in Docetaxal/Tax has anyone else had this? Will it still...

Posts.Content: Thx Mistymoley not thinking straight just taken the Tramadol as you say no good in the packet. Just hope I can get some relief. I’ve taken Tramadol before after one of my ops so hopefully can cope with the side effects. Going on the settee now until my husband gets in to cook the dinner!
Posts.Title: HOW LONG!

Posts.Content: Thx for the info Suzi I have taken note and will certainly be prepared for the next one. The Tramadol I took nearly an hour ago has kicked in and just feeling a bit spaced out but not hunched up and tense with the pain like I was. Temp’s OK as well, hope your keeping good.
Posts.Title: HOW LONG!

Posts.Content: Thx JP so sorry to hear you are having a worse time than me, here’s hoping you soon feel better. This journey is certainly not for the faint hearted. Thx Jessie, no injection I’m having the Docetaxal as a drip infusion, didn’t know you could have as an injection. Although saying that I have a PICC line in (useless veins) so perhaps that’s why. One things for sure we are never alone on this site thank goodness. Thx Saxxyd. From what you have said and others this Docetaxal seems to be a right b….r. Going to check temp now.
Posts.Title: HOW LONG!

Posts.Content: Afternoon all had my 1st Docetaxal last Thursday. Started to get aches and pains yesterday but today feel like c..p! Aching bones all over, headache, sore mouth and everything tastes terrible. Taking Ibuprofen and Paracetamol for pain and Difflam for throat. Also got Tramadol if I need it. Anyone got any idea how long this lasts! Sorry to be a wimp just want some inspiration to keep positive. Keep telling myself at least that’s 4 of 6 done only 2 to go and usually can smile but not today. Thx for any feedback.
Posts.Title: HOW LONG!

Posts.Content: Morning everyone please can someone explain about the "black nail varnish" when on Docetaxel. I will having one more FEC then 3 Docetaxel and would like to be prepared.Thx
Posts.Title: Black nail varnish & Docetaxel

Posts.Content: Thx for all your replies. Black nail varnish on this weeks shopping list. i will try to perserve what I can. I look online most days but having trouble "publishing" sometimes it works sometimes no good but take heart at all your blogs. I don't feel as if I'm on my own. good luck to you all with your hourneys.
Posts.Title: Black nail varnish & Docetaxel

Posts.Content: Thought I had best update you all on my present situation. I finished the “T” end of October and the radio end of November. Was given Anastrozole as the hormone suppressant but did not agree with me so was then given Exemestane which I’ve been on for two weeks but the verdict is still out as to whether this is the correct one for me. By painting my finger and toe nails before having “T” and ever since I can report that I still have all nails albeit slightly discoloured. I think I will continue with this for another month before going “nude”. I was lucky to be accepted to the “FAST FORWARD” programme and instead of having three weeks of radio I only had 1 week which finished the end of November and I can report no problems. I showered with simple soap and moisturised with Aloe Vera gel (99.9%) and aqueous cream given to me by the hospital. On finishing the chemo I was given a bone density scan which revealed that I had osteoporosis which has meant that I am now on Alendronic Acid and Calcichew-D3 to help replace/repair the reduced bone mass. Following the chemo end of November I still suffer from extremely bad muscle/bone ache and have to take Tramadol for the pain albeit lower dose now ( 2 tablets a day) but desperately want to get off these and get on with my life. I have appointments with the chemo onc at the end of January and the radio onc beginning of February when I hope I will get some sense! Apart from that I’m OK. Here’s hoping you all fare as well as me if not better. I keep an eye out on this site and if I think I can assist anyone I try. Good luck to you all.
Posts.Title: Black nail varnish & Docetaxel

Posts.Content: Hi Julie is was the same as me. However doc gave me Tramadol for the pain which worked but try not to get too dependent on it as takes a while to get off (narcotic). Not sure about the cough would be good idea to ask at same time as asking for stronger pain killers. I had sore mouth and throat and was given Nystatin which also worked. Don't suffer there's always something they can give you for the side affects. Hope you soon get sorted, hugsxx
Posts.Title: Taking longer to recover from 2nd cycle of docetaxel/cyclophospha...

Posts.Content: Morning AA poor you not nice. I was given a “CHEMOTHERAPY ALERT CARD” which gives me emergency numbers at the hospital that I can ring day or night. If you have one contact them straight away for assistance, if not I would suggest you contact the A & E department at the hospital. Don’t wait until Monday you need help now! Hope you get sorted today lots of hugs.
Posts.Title: Embarassing, but I need relief!
